articles.headline: Pakistani Leader to Exit Army Job, His Rival Reports
articles.snippet: Gen. Pervez Musharraf would resign as army chief and serve another term as president and former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto would return to Pakistan.
articles.abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf would resign as army chief and serve another term as president and former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto would return to Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 29 — The exiled former prime minister Benazir Bhutto said Wednesday that Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, had agreed to resign as army chief as part of a nearly completed deal that would allow him to serve another term as president if he is re-elected and allow her to return to Pakistan to run for prime minister.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Salman Masood

articles.headline: Virginia Tech Criticized for Actions in Shooting
articles.snippet: A panel said officials could have saved lives last April by notifying students and faculty members earlier about killings on campus.
articles.abstract: A panel said officials could have saved lives last April by notifying students and faculty members earlier about killings on campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 29 — A state panel has sharply criticized decisions made by Virginia Tech before and after last April’s shooting massacre, saying university officials could have saved lives by notifying students and faculty members earlier about the killings on campus.

articles.headline: Mending a Bruised Image
articles.snippet: Worried by the growing image of athletes gone wild, the N.F.L. is embarking on an advertising effort that highlights the positive aspects of the lives of its players.
articles.abstract: Worried by the growing image of athletes gone wild, the N.F.L. is embarking on an advertising effort that highlights the positive aspects of the lives of its players.
articles.lead_paragraph: In one spot, a father sits on the sofa with his young children, reading to them from a large book while a daughter nestles her head on his neck.

articles.headline: Organic Dairy Agrees to Alter Some Practices
articles.snippet: Colorado’s Aurora Organic Dairy agreed Wednesday to stop applying the organic label to some of its milk and to make major changes in its operations after its organic certification was threatened.
articles.abstract: Colorado’s Aurora Organic Dairy agreed Wednesday to stop applying the organic label to some of its milk and to make major changes in its operations after its organic certification was threatened.
articles.lead_paragraph: A huge Colorado organic dairy agreed yesterday to stop applying the organic label to some of its milk and make major changes in its operation after the Department of Agriculture threatened to revoke its organic certification for, among other problems, failing to provide enough pasture to its cows.

articles.headline: Doctors Offering No-Interest Loans to Patients
articles.snippet: Zero-interest financing for medical procedures has become one of the fastest-growing segments of consumer credit.
articles.abstract: Zero-interest financing for medical procedures has become one of the fastest-growing segments of consumer credit.

articles.headline: An Investor Activism Uncommon in Japan
articles.snippet: After 31 years as a civil servant, Tomomi Yano began to take on Japan’s corporate culture, and has become an unlikely and remarkably successful advocate for shareholder rights.
articles.abstract: After 31 years as a civil servant, Tomomi Yano began to take on Japan’s corporate culture, and has become an unlikely and remarkably successful advocate for shareholder rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Aug. 29 — Tomomi Yano was an unlikely maverick. When the unassuming Mr. Yano became head of investment at one of Japan’s biggest pension funds in 2001, corporate executives here assumed that he was simply another former bureaucrat parachuting into semiretirement. Japan’s vast government-run pension system, the reasoning went, would provide a comfortable nest after his 31 years at the labor ministry.

articles.headline: Clinton Donor Under a Cloud in Fraud Case
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign said it would give away thousands of dollars that it received from a Democratic donor who is considered a fugitive in California.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign said it would give away thousands of dollars that it received from a Democratic donor who is considered a fugitive in California.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign said yesterday that it would give to charity $23,000 it had received from a prominent Democratic donor, and review thousands of dollars more that he had raised, after learning that the authorities in California had a warrant for his arrest stemming from a 1991 fraud case.
articles.byline: By Mike McIntire and Leslie Wayne

articles.headline: Marines’ Trials in Iraq Killings Are Withering
articles.snippet: Prosecutors have had trouble obtaining convictions of the marines charged with killing civilians in Haditha, Iraq.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors have had trouble obtaining convictions of the marines charged with killing civilians in Haditha, Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Aug. 29 — Last December, when the Marine Corps charged four infantrymen with killing Iraqi civilians in Haditha, Iraq, in 2005, the allegation was as dark as it was devastating: after a roadside bomb had killed their buddy, a group of marines rampaged through nearby homes, massacring 24 innocent people.

articles.headline: A Camera for Generation Z
articles.snippet: Fujifilm includes several youth-oriented features in its new Z10fd camera.
articles.abstract: Fujifilm includes several youth-oriented features in its new Z10fd camera.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first decade of the digital camera revolution, most manufacturers dangled only one carrot in front of prospective buyers: more megapixels. You felt inferior if your camera took 3-megapixel photos when the latest models had 5.

articles.headline: Stocks Rally as Investors Chase Deals
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke said the Federal Reserve was “prepared to act as needed” to prevent market woes from spreading, while the Dow closed up nearly 250 points as investors went bargain-hunting.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke said the Federal Reserve was “prepared to act as needed” to prevent market woes from spreading, while the Dow closed up nearly 250 points as investors went bargain-hunting.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market recovered almost all of its losses from Tuesday’s sharp sell-off as investors went bargain-hunting yesterday at Wall Street’s equivalent of a late summer sale.
